title: 112_s564
content: The Valles Caldera National Preserve Management Act establishes definitions for terms like "eligible employee," "Fund," "Preserve," "Secretary," "State," and "Trust." The Act also defines the Valles Caldera National Preserve in New Mexico. The Valles Caldera National Preserve is designated as a unit of the National Park System to protect various values of the area. The Secretary will administer the Preserve in accordance with applicable laws and may coordinate management with Bandelier National Monument. A management plan must be developed within three fiscal years of funds availability. The Secretary will prepare a management plan for the Valles Caldera National Preserve within three fiscal years, in consultation with various entities including the Secretary of Agriculture, State and local governments, and Indian tribes. The plan will be developed in accordance with relevant laws. The Secretary may acquire land within the Preserve from various sources such as purchase, donation, or transfer from another Federal agency. Acquired land will be administered as part of the Preserve. The Secretary is responsible for carrying out the science and education program established by the Trust until a management plan is completed. The Secretary is responsible for carrying out the science and education program for the Preserve until a management plan is completed. Once the plan is completed, a new program will be established to allow for research, ecological restoration, and outdoor educational experiences in the Preserve. Additionally, a science and education center may be established outside the Preserve boundaries. The Secretary may establish a science and education center outside the Preserve boundaries. Grazing of livestock within the Preserve is allowed for scientific research or interpretation of ranching history. The Secretary, in consultation with the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish, may permit hunting and fishing within the Preserve according to applicable laws. Zones may be designated where hunting or fishing is not allowed for reasons of safety, wildlife protection, or public enjoyment. The Secretary can designate zones in the Preserve where no hunting or fishing is allowed for public safety, wildlife protection, or public enjoyment. The Secretary is also responsible for ecological restoration activities in the Preserve, including cooperating with adjacent pueblos. All land within the Preserve boundaries is withdrawn from public land laws, mining laws, and other forms of appropriation. Interests in land within the boundaries of the Preserve are withdrawn from entry, disposal, or appropriation under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. Volcanic domes and other peaks above 9,600 feet in elevation are protected from construction of roads or buildings and motorized access. The volcanic domes and peaks above 9,600 feet in elevation protected from construction and motorized access include Redondo Peak, Redondito, South Mountain, San Antonio Mountain, Cerro Seco, Cerro San Luis, Cerros Santa Rosa, Cerros del Abrigo, Cerro del Medio, Rabbit Mountain, Cerro Grande, Cerro Toledo, Indian Point, Sierra de los Valles, and Cerros de los Posos. Exceptions apply for administrative purposes or emergencies. The Secretary will ensure protection of traditional cultural and religious sites in the Preserve, providing access to Indian tribes and pueblos for customary uses. Motorized access is prohibited to maintain the sanctity of these areas. The Secretary will study the feasibility of establishing a hiking trail along the rim of the Valles Caldera within the Preserve and adjacent National Forest System land, in consultation with affected Indian tribes and pueblos. Agreements may be sought with the tribes or pueblos upon request. The Secretary and the Secretary of Agriculture will seek agreements with affected Indian tribes or pueblos regarding the Caldera Rim Trail to protect cultural and religious sites and the privacy of adjacent pueblo land. Valid existing rights are not affected by this Act. SEC. 4. TRANSFER OF ADMINISTRATIVE JURISDICTION. The Preserve's administrative jurisdiction is transferred to the Secretary for management as part of the National Park System. The Santa Fe National Forest boundaries are adjusted to exclude the Preserve. An interim management agreement will facilitate the transition of administration to the Secretary, who can follow existing management plans until a new one is developed. The Valles Caldera Trust will terminate unless the Secretary extends it for transitional management. Upon termination, all Trust assets will transfer to the Secretary, and any appropriated funds will be available for Preserve administration. Upon termination of the Valles Caldera Trust, all assets will transfer to the Secretary for Preserve administration. The Secretary will assume all contracts, obligations, and liabilities of the Trust, and a budget must be prepared for interim management with written concurrence required for new liabilities. The Trust must obtain written approval from the Secretary for any new liabilities not authorized in the budget. The Secretary and the Secretary of Agriculture can hire Trust employees for similar positions at the Preserve or other areas. Hired employees are subject to specific pay regulations. Eligible employees can be retained for at least 180 days after the Trust's termination. The Trust must obtain approval from the Secretary for new liabilities. Employees can be retained for 180 days after termination. The Secretary has access to all Trust records. The Secretary shall assume powers over the Valles caldera fund from the Trust, with access to all records for management of the Preserve. Amounts in the Fund are available for use by the Secretary without further appropriation. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF VALLES CALDERA PRESERVATION ACT. On termination of the Trust, the Valles Caldera Preservation Act is repealed. The Secretary of Agriculture's authority to acquire mineral interests is transferred, provisions related to the Pueblo of Santa Clara remain, and the Fund will not be terminated until all amounts are expended. Boundaries of the Preserve and Santa Fe National Forest remain unaffected by the repeal. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act is repealed upon termination of the Trust. The boundaries of the Preserve, Santa Fe National Forest, Bandelier National Monument, and land conveyed to the Pueblo of Santa Clara remain unaffected. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for carrying out this Act can be appropriated.
